intro: Comolia parvifolia, commonly known as the small-leaved comolia, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central America. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its small, oval-shaped leaves and showy, pale yellow to white flowers that bloom in summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and requires full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
